Award.AwardTitle: Comparing infants' and adults' learning of three types of linguistic generalizations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research addresses two puzzles about language: Only humans have it, and learning a language as an infant results in better language skill than learning as an adult. Learning a language entails discovering rules, such as the English rule that the plural ending on nouns either sounds like "z" as in "kids" or like "s" as in "kits". In simplified terms, the rule is: add the "z" sound if the word ends in a voiced consonant ("d" is made with vocal cords vibrating) OR add the "s" sound if the word ends in a voiceless consonant (no vocal cord vibration for "t"). 11-month-olds can learn an "OR" rule from just 4 words of an invented language, but adults cannot learn the rule even from 76 words. Non-human animals, like human adults, also fail to learn OR rules in the visual domain (e.g., press the button for either small black squares OR large white triangles). Thus, infants are adept at learning a type of rule that is frequent in human language, but that adults and animals do not easily learn. Understanding why infants succeed so easily promises to reveal differences in how adults and infants learn language, and will perhaps allow superior, infant-like, language learning by computers.

Infants are exposed to words from an invented language that reflects one of three types of rules (the OR rule or 2 other types that are more easily learned by adults and animals). Their rule learning is tested by measuring their attention to new words that reflect the same or a different rule. Adults are exposed to the same words under several conditions that are designed to improve learning of the OR rule. Their rule learning is tested by asking them to rate new words on their similarity to the words that they just heard.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many people know that learning language as an infant results in better final language abilities than learning language as an adult. But why? One impediment to answering the "why" question is that research on infant and adult learning in the laboratory typically finds similar abilities, or superior adult abilities. Therefore, it would be very helpful to find an example of language learning that is better accomplished by infants than by adults. The research supported by this project has succeeded in finding exactly that. Infants are able to learn a rule or pattern of language in which the two consonants in a Consonant-Vowel-Consonant-Vowel word must both be voiced (made with vocal cords vibrating) or both voiceless (made with vocal cords not vibrating). Infants can learn this rule from just 4 words, but adults cannot learn from 4 or from more than 80 input words. One of the most important findings of the current research is that if we test infants in a way more similar to adults, dividing the test items into those that fit the voiced half of the rule and others that fit the voiceless half of the rule, infants learn both halves. This result makes it clear that there is a real developmental difference in how infants and adults learn some aspects of language. We can robustly show this difference in the lab, opening the door to laboratory explorations that answer the "why" question.

One answer to the "why" question that we have explored for infants' superior learning of some types of rules is that adults process all language input through the sound-based lexicon, which is associatively organized. That is, words that share sound properties are "closer" to each other in the mental store of words. One problem with the rule or pattern just described is that it really involves two subpatterns - words in which both consonants are voiced and others in which both consonants are voiceless. Such patterns, often called Exclusive OR, or XOR, are impossible to learn in an associatively organized system like the adult lexicon. Thus, we hypothesize that adults are good at learning rules or patterns that involve associative relations, but not XOR relations. One such associative rule that is on the surface very similar to the XOR rule is called a Family Resemblance Rule. An example of such a rule is that each word must have at least 2 out of 3 of the following features: Consonant 1 is voiced, Consonant 2 is voiced, Vowel 1 is made in the front of the mouth. Adults readily learn this rule. Interestingly, adults with a history of language impairment also readily learn the Family Resemblance rule, consistent with other evidence that their sound-based lexicon has a largely normal, associative, organization. This finding flies in the face of theories suggesting that children and adults with language impairment are not good at learning implicit rules or patterns of language. Therefore, the adult findings open the door to thinking about new theories of normal and disordered language development. In addition, the adult research suggests some ways in which we might better teach second languages. Specifically focusing on word learning forces adults to process the new language through the lexicon, which might prevent them from learning XOR rules in their new language.

In addition to the findings about infants learning some types of language patterns better than adults, and adults with a history of language impairment showing normal learning of some types of patterns, the current research also explored ways of testing infants online. This outcome was forced upon us by the COVID-19 epidemic, but the result is a much wider infant demographic base than we had when we just tested Tucson infants in the lab. Therefore, we can feel more confident that our results reflect the abilities of a broad range of infants.

In summary, the project addressed a long-acknowledged mystery in human learning - learning language as an infant results in better performance than learning as an adult. The project provides a clear example of infants learning better than adults in the lab, as well as a possible explanation that can impact both second language pedagogy and theories of atypical language development.
